data.text: The value of fraud involving cards issued in Single Euro Payments Area countries accounted for only 0.036% of the total value of transactions in 2019. This is just one finding from our report on card fraud. Read our press release for more https://t.co/C2XBWHgwGP
Euro area economic and financial developments by institutional sector (Q2 2021) https://t.co/vk84aBC9fO
Economic Bulletin box: Main findings from the ECB’s recent contacts with non-financial companies https://t.co/NYoSmFrsZd
Revoir : la présidente @Lagarde sur les goulets d’étranglement du côté de l’offre, l’un des éléments qui poussent actuellement l’inflation à la hausse https://t.co/gi24qAwbHg
Pressekonferenz verpasst? EZB-Präsidentin @Lagarde zu Lieferengpässen, die zu den aktuellen Inflationstreibern zählen https://t.co/dq5VJFdIVo
Watch again: President @Lagarde on supply bottlenecks as one of the elements currently pushing up inflation https://t.co/IlID42xCMM
Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/kj1hdOcUPb https://t.co/udSi94yHS1

Financing conditions in the economy remain favourable.

The positive effects of our pandemic emergency purchase programme keep helping consumers, companies, and the public sector.

Read more https://t.co/OU85YI97z4

4/4 https://t.co/54GolGezPw

The current higher inflation is mainly because oil, gas and electricity prices have gone up a lot and demand is rising faster than supply with the reopening of the economy.

But we expect inflation to fall in the course of 2022 as these issues fade away

3/4 https://t.co/53LfuZGnxu

The economy is being held back by:

➡️ not enough materials, equipment and workers in some sectors
➡️ deliveries taking longer
➡️ transport and energy prices increasing a lot

2/4 https://t.co/6jEDV9ZaiI

Today’s monetary policy statement at a glance – a thread:

The pandemic’s grip on the economy has loosened. People are confident about the future and keep spending.

But the growth momentum has moderated to some extent

1/4 https://t.co/8jCirmL4NS

President @Lagarde has just presented the Governing Council’s monetary policy statement.

Read the statement https://t.co/kj1hdOcUPb

Topic tags are currently available for selected content on the ECB website. We will keep working to tag other parts of our website. Let us know if you find our topic tags useful in the comments below ⬇️ 3/3

We’ve compiled a list of all the available topics so you can browse them easily. Clicking on a topic will take you to a list of related content. You can also see the topic tags for a specific publication, like a speech or a press release, at the bottom of the page 2/3

(THREAD) Looking for everything our Executive Board members have said about inflation or their latest comments on climate change? Head to our website where we've started tagging content based on its topic to help you find information quickly and easily https://t.co/4TrPogTSH7 1/3 https://t.co/eGK8W7RVrk
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in September? How do they compare with August's figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/25fLgFhc0O https://t.co/vodDlBIBZ6
The link to the livestream provided in the earlier tweet does not seem to be working. You can follow the event via the following link: https://t.co/jjcJ9GEvnu https://t.co/A7TLxtiHCK

Watch live from 14:45 CET: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria joins an @EBA_News panel discussing financial integration in the EU over the last ten years https://t.co/sQpHST1d7d
#EBA10yEARS https://t.co/HZCMnFs8nT

Capital markets are key to achieving carbon neutrality. Sustainable financial products make up less than 10% of their respective markets in the euro area, but green capital markets are growing rapidly. Read more in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/bW0F6NCxKt https://t.co/GmM1jIAMdL
We asked 146 banks in the euro area about changes in their lending behaviour and loan demand during the third quarter of 2021. Find out the results https://t.co/VvGqxX8PoQ https://t.co/DatAEBAPzw
ECB announces members of Digital Euro Market Advisory Group https://t.co/FJo3usNFUU

European banks can get more out of the single market by establishing branches or providing services in other EU countries, says Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo. We don’t have to wait for new legislation to increase banking integration https://t.co/20S7V4QB5X https://t.co/41OrI7abBn

Green prudential policies decrease financial stability risks, our analysis shows. Without them, transition risks can lead to excessive risk-taking by banks, increasing the volatility in the economy. Read more in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/bW0F6NCxKt https://t.co/chJcFyhl3w

The euro area bank interest rate on loans for house purchases fell from 3.98% in August 2011 to 1.32% in August 2021. Explore our latest statistical insights on house price developments and loans to households in 23 EU languages https://t.co/sqe1sho1T3 https://t.co/pjd0Ouvpap

“We safeguard the quality of statistics and provide trustworthy facts for the public debate” says our Director General Statistics Silke Stapel Weber. Why do statistics matter for us? Read our explainer https://t.co/jwrcZzcTCI

Today we’re celebrating #EuropeanStatisticsDay! Accurate and timely data are essential to making informed decisions. They help us keep prices stable and serve the 343 million people who use the euro every day. Check the infographic for some key figures about the euro area⬇️ https://t.co/laJCtsH3cC

We are a proud member of the Ethics Network of Multilateral Organisations. Our membership helps us to learn from each other’s experiences around the world so we can implement the highest ethical standards. Find out more about the network 2/2 https://t.co/TyICLzprt2

(THREAD) Today is #GlobalEthicsDay! We at the @ECB are dedicated to acting with impartiality, integrity and respect. We collaborate with authorities across Europe and worldwide to ensure that we are ethical in everything we do 1/2 https://t.co/N4PxJU5R9K https://t.co/r3cZHXW3bx
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Aug 2021) https://t.co/f0aHwz3hIW

Europe’s pledge to become carbon neutral by 2050 will change its economies, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Frank Elderson. Banks must develop plans with clear milestones in line with EU climate policies that help them successfully manage the transition https://t.co/1hdBkUx0wR https://t.co/nFOwJutA10

Tune in from 9:20 CET: Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Frank Elderson talks about the need for banks to plan for a smooth transition to a greener economy at the @FMA_AT https://t.co/oxQ2mMiYIc https://t.co/sSKjKZZnoy

Panetta: It may be beneficial to discuss common standards, for instance to make central bank digital currency projects interoperable and allow cross-currency payments between CBDCs, and to limit the impact on the international monetary system.
4/4

Panetta: Not all central banks are moving at the same pace and different objectives, legal frameworks, financial structures and preferences will be reflected in different CBDC designs. But international cooperation can help find a consensus on issues of common interest.
3/4

Panetta: CBDC features (safety, liquidity, efficiency, scalability) mean its use by non-residents might:
➡️increase currency substitution risks for weaker economies   
➡️magnify the cross-border transmission of shocks
➡️support the international role of the issuing currency
2/4

Decisions about central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) like a digital euro require a careful assessment of the international implications, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. This requires further research and international cooperation.
Speech https://t.co/Ik6F0iIfXA
1/4 https://t.co/Jq0HFXkGQl

Follow live today at 16:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane will participate in a panel discussion on experiences from central banks’ strategy reviews at the @SuomenPankki and @suerf_org joint conference on monetary policy approaches https://t.co/ly81cZIGpj https://t.co/5jZZQWnOhe

Green capital markets are growing rapidly and are more resilient and integrated than traditional markets. Enhancing market structures and standards will limit greenwashing and drive the growth of green finance, helping bring about carbon neutrality https://t.co/OXW3BWkpZ5  
6/6

Banks tend to take excessive risks when they don’t identify transition risks in their capital requirement calculations. This increases volatility in the economy. Introducing prudential climate policies could help address this https://t.co/fMnBzlrwnp  
5/6

Climate-focused macroprudential stress tests can help ensure timely and appropriate policy responses to climate risks. We propose an approach that recognises that climate risks add to other deep-seated cyclical and structural risks in the economy https://t.co/NKk6Z6LXg8  
4/6

The EU taxonomy for sustainable economic activities is an important tool to encourage investment in green activities. How green are euro area investors and what investments are needed to meet the EU’s 2030 climate targets? https://t.co/t3g9zBkUKW 
3/6

It’s difficult to accurately capture the impact of climate risk on bank balance sheets. To ensure financial stability, macroprudential policies may be needed to complement banks’ own risk management processes and direct supervision https://t.co/bD1w8pqvZR 
2/6

(THREAD) Our Macroprudential Bulletin on climate risk is out! This issue explores the tools and policy reforms needed to manage climate risks and finance the transition towards a greener economy https://t.co/bW0F6NCxKt 

Here’s a quick overview of the topics ⬇️
1/6 https://t.co/vEugb2peZZ

The stress test will help improve data availability and quality, and allow us to better understand banks’ stress-testing frameworks for climate risks. The output will feed into the Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP) based on a qualitative approach
2/2

(THREAD) We’ve today shared the methodology for our 2022 stress test on climate risks with the banks we directly supervise. We consider this stress test to be a learning exercise for banks and supervisors alike https://t.co/BI2tC6ZYq5
1/2 https://t.co/Gey2Omms7z
Working Paper: The transmission of euro area monetary policy to financially euroised countries https://t.co/O1GjTkqePe

Lagarde: Europe must strengthen its own domestic demand by:

 ➡️ steering investment towards the green and digital sectors of the future
➡️ ensuring fiscal policy support is not withdrawn prematurely and is correctly targeted 
➡️ supporting the economy with monetary policy

4/4

Lagarde: Instead, we should use our economic weight to shape openness in a European direction characterised by
 
➡️ being reasonable rather than reactionary
➡️ cooperation rather than conflict
➡️ redistributing the gains of globalisation to those who have lost out

3/4

Lagarde: There are two priorities, both of which would help Europe act as an anchor of stability in a more fractured and uncertain world.
 
First, turning our back on trade openness is not the answer.
 
2/4

(THREAD) A world in transition means Europe must adapt if we are to continue reaping the benefits of globalisation, says President Christine @Lagarde as she delivers the Per Jacobsson lecture.

Read her full remarks https://t.co/KELbCHPFcN
1/4 https://t.co/klz4IIw0k1

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper https://t.co/wbqetNvJyM  
5/5

Macroeconomic models can be further enhanced, for example by:
1⃣ specifying the expectations formation process
2⃣ accounting for exogenous long-term trends
3⃣ adapting them to things like climate change and larger shocks such as the coronavirus pandemic
4/5

The models we use provide a flexible framework for conducting projection exercises and analysing alternative policy options. The suite-of-models approach achieves a good balance between model diversity and specialisation for different uses
3/5

A suite-of-models approach is typically used across the Eurosystem. Although this approach was already in use during our 2003 strategy review, now we use a wider variety of models and existing models have been improved
2/5

(THREAD) We use macroeconomic models to help prepare our monetary policy decisions and build baseline projections. We conducted an assessment of these models as part of our strategy review https://t.co/wbqetNvJyM 
1/5 https://t.co/S6gT0t91B4
Working Paper: Estimating the elasticity of consumer prices to the exchange rate - An accounting approach https://t.co/oItKmFFkAK
Working Paper: The ECB's tracker - Nowcasting the press conferences of the ECB https://t.co/WWmgX2tUIQ

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper https://t.co/oCrDWgCmZr 
4/4

3⃣Side effects have generally been limited so far, but they vary over time and need to be monitored closely

4⃣Our toolkit needs to always be innovative, diversified, flexible and current to remain fit for purpose in our changing world 
3/4

1⃣Our monetary policy has effectively eased financing conditions since 2014, supported economic growth, employment and brought inflation closer to our target

2⃣Combining different instruments is more effective than relying on a single tool in a low interest rate environment
2/4

(THREAD) Over the past few years we introduced new monetary policy instruments to achieve our price stability objective.
We looked at their efficiency and potential side effects as part of our strategy review.
Four key findings⬇️ https://t.co/oCrDWgCmZr
1/4 https://t.co/SEKNlloGdK
See our visual monetary policy statement for a simple explanation of our latest decisions https://t.co/PGRoRRt9vd https://t.co/8aqHzKR8Yg

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper
https://t.co/5VFnYiZdlK  
4/4

Historically, the ECB and national central banks across the euro area have focused on communicating with expert audiences.
Better communication with the general public can boost people’s trust in us and make monetary policy more effective by steering inflation expectations.
3/4

Communication helps manage expectations and economic outcomes, so that central banks can deliver on their mandate and keep prices stable.
For example, forward guidance has provided additional monetary stimulus in times of low inflation and low interest rates in the euro area
2/4

(THREAD) Central bank communication has become a monetary policy tool in its own right. Speaking clearly, consistently and effectively is essential for the credibility, accountability and legitimacy of independent central banks today https://t.co/5VFnYiZdlK 
1/4 https://t.co/ARyLOWRzig

Enria: We are pushing for a more integrated banking market, relying on the tools available. However, we need the support of legislators to achieve real progress towards the completion of the banking union
3/3

Enria: We are looking at the risks posed by banks’ excessive search for yield, which is feeding complexity and opacity in financial markets
2/3

Lane: Calibrating the volume of asset purchases plays an important role in ensuring that the monetary stance is sufficiently accommodative to deliver on our inflation target in a timely manner https://t.co/jK4WnEJpHF 4/4
Lane: A one-off shift in the level of wages as part of the adjustment to a transitory unexpected increase in the price level does not imply a trend shift in the path of underlying inflation 3/4
Lane: Our interest rate policy should not react to inflation shocks expected to fade before the end of our projection horizon. We need to see realised progress in underlying inflation 2/4

(THREAD) Inflation needs to reach 2% well ahead of the end of our projection horizon and durably for the rest of it, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane opening the ECB Conference on Monetary Policy. Speech https://t.co/jK4WnEJpHF 1/4 https://t.co/87s1ArGRZj

Want to know who contributed to this research? Check out the list of all authors and contributors from the ECB and national central banks across the euro area in the full occasional paper https://t.co/rnUSA1Flcc   
3/3

Further improvements are needed. The methodology for handling product replacement, quality adjustments and sampling issues should be further harmonised. There is still a gap in knowledge about the size of HICP measurement bias, which calls for more research
2/3

(THREAD) The Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices remains the most appropriate framework for measuring inflation. It could be enhanced by including owner-occupied housing – a finding supported by the results of our ECB Listens events https://t.co/rnUSA1Flcc  
1/3 https://t.co/Xvdh8d4gGb

Panetta: Regulation is necessary, but we need to do more: central bank digital currencies such as a digital euro would facilitate a level playing field for financial intermediaries and provide an anchor of stability for the payments and digital finance ecosystem 4/4

Panetta: We will need domestic and international  cooperation among the relevant authorities to contain the risks that digital finance poses to public policy goals such as financial stability, fair competition, anti-money laundering efforts, consumer protection and privacy 3/4

Panetta: We could see risk-biased technological change, whereby the confluence of big techs’ increasing role in finance and the growth of digital assets such as crypto-assets and stablecoins could bring about sudden and disruptive risks for the global economy 2/4

(THREAD) Without proper regulation, the expansion of digital finance could amplify international shocks and undermine financial resilience globally, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. 
Read the speech https://t.co/efDBc0uQ4s
1/4 https://t.co/HzPi4Tf1x5
